question.text: According to the concept of species-area relationship:

options.text: The number of species in an area increases with the size of the area .
The value of Z lies in the range of 0.3 to 0.4, regardless of the taxonomic group or the region.
The relationship is for a rectangular hyperbola curve is described by the equation log S = log C + Z log A.
The larger the area the greater the extinction rate.

solution.text: German naturalist and geographer Alexander von Humboldt, after his studies in south american jungles, observed that within a specific region species richness is increased with increasing area, but only up to a limit. Exactly the relation between species richness and area for a wide variety of taxa (angiosperm plants, birds, bats, freshwater fishes) was found to be a rectangular hyperbola.
